column1: '''Atlantis-haunting''' or  '''Atlantic complex''' refers to [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]'s recurring dreams of the city of an island being consumed by the ocean.
{{quote|This legend or myth or dim memory of some ancient history has always troubled me. In sleep I had the dreadful dream of the ineluctable Wave
column2: either coming out of the quiet sea
column3: or coming in towering over the green inlands. It still occurs occasionally
column4: though now exorcized by writing about it. It always ends by surrender
column5: and I awake gasping out of deep water. I used to draw it or write bad poems about it.|[[J.R.R. Tolkien]]

column1: It was this dream that inspired the story of the [[Downfall of Númenor]]. In ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]''
column2: the Professor transfers his dream to [[Faramir]] who dreams of the Downfall of Númenor. Tolkien believed his dream may have been passed down from his parents as his son
column4: had similar dreams and Tolkien had never mentioned it to him.
